689480D7CECB4F06953646D5A3C14955.description: Systems in dynamic equilibrium are stable due to a balance of feedback mechanisms.

FD8F294501CA4D729049C3DC14D81D28.description: Stability might be disturbed either by sudden events or gradual changes that accumulate over time.

0F5348F7731A47F0BD9D29C549E6EBA9.description: Small changes in one part of a system might cause large changes in another part.

5A04173F399F488B93A512115BBCA324.description: Explanations of stability and change in natural or designed systems can be constructed by examining the changes over time and forces at different scales, including the atomic scale.

D948047E9B7B4BCFA6E2A4818D121BBB.description: Stability and Change – For both designed and natural systems, conditions that affect stability and factors that control rates of change are critical elements to consider and understand.

252532F50CC840DC8F3210C42901E8D4.description: Structures can be designed to serve particular functions by taking into account properties of different materials, and how materials can be shaped and used.

0289A055DF924940A33FD38D82F6A3F2.description: Complex and microscopic structures and systems can be visualized, modeled, and used to describe how their function depends on the shapes, composition, and relationships among its parts; therefore, complex natural and designed structures/systems can be analyzed to determine how they function.

A3B7A3B12A204259BF3F0FFE35E3F59B.description: Structure and Function – The way an object is shaped or structured determines many of its properties and functions

CE32779F0A2342ECBD6E7525401E825C.description: The transfer of energy can be tracked as energy flows through a designed or natural system.

2776E1FAF497454AAC6769063EA4088C.description: Energy may take different forms (e.g. energy in fields, thermal energy, energy of motion).

25F28A7E022B49889B14065F51E074BE.description: Within a natural or designed system, the transfer of energy drives the motion and/or cycling of matter.

B2F5276CADA841F484724D2FF8A4290A.description: Matter is conserved because atoms are conserved in physical and chemical processes.

01C27CACB68047C3A8E9261EED992502.description: Energy and Matter: Flows, Cycles, and Conservation – Tracking energy and matter flows, into, out of, and within systems helps one understand their system’s behavior

70DE6EFE959A42349C7E449AE2B044CD.description: Models are limited in that they only represent certain aspects of the system under study

B8C2D593D3DB441AB65F5C38EB841E4A.description: Models can be used to represent systems and their interactions—such as inputs, processes and outputs—and energy, matter, and information flows within systems.

DF0EDFC35BDA45F79AE8B6A36E00DC47.description: Systems may interact with other systems; they may have sub-systems and be a part of larger complex systems.

65445051761E45A88E65FFA39DC0662A.description: Systems and System Models – A system is an organized group of related objects or components; models can be used for understanding and predicting the behavior of systems.

2D6D440CB27241B1B2197C11CC953C7C.description: Phenomena that can be observed at one scale may not be observable at another scale

BEE10BC1A5DB497EB8A21F9E5CD23AFA.description: Scientific relationships can be represented through the use of algebraic expressions and equations.

BE4D2830B4904D4FB9C530A32C7F0BDF.description: Proportional relationships (e.g., speed as the ratio of distance traveled to time taken) among different types of quantities provide information about the magnitude of properties and processes.

E31742EC349B40A7AD42FC686244E994.description: The observed function of natural and designed systems may change with scale.

32E171FBDFA34AADA7EA70B75B8CA166.description: Time, space, and energy phenomena can be observed at various scales using models to study systems that are too large or too small.

FB06252ECFD04EBB8C915DA09081E5FA.description: Scale, Proportion, and Quantity – In considering phenomena, it is critical to recognize what is relevant at different size, time, and energy scales, and to recognize proportional relationships between different quantities as scales change.

B5444587BD2249518DF625EA860E1D7E.description: Phenomena may have more than one cause, and some cause and effect relationships in systems can only be described using probability.

4BD84BD953C044D497393658078489F4.description: Cause and effect relationships may be used to predict phenomena in natural or designed systems.

A47245CD5D1F42E58C1A145290DB213A.description: Relationships can be classified as causal or correlational, and correlation does not necessarily imply causation.

2934A65B925D461D88410679E70CD186.description: Cause and Effect: Mechanism and Prediction – Events have causes, sometimes simple, sometimes multifaceted. Deciphering causal relationships, and the mechanisms by which they are mediated, is a major activity of science and engineering.

DEC0B76311274D3BBE14BDB90832BD8B.description: Graphs, charts, and images can be used to identify patterns in data.

68288978E0554B859AFBD9A311CEDA50.description: Patterns can be used to identify cause and effect relationships.

9BDD5401A294421FA543DC94C94AA42B.description: Patterns in rates of change and other numerical relationships can provide information about natural and human designed systems.

DD8769C1B8BB45D6A7614D0BA57D2994.description: Macroscopic patterns are related to the nature of microscopic and atomic-level structure.

B428AA311A494D849AD4BA9889CE5672.description: Patterns – Observed patterns in nature guide organization and classification and prompt questions about relationships and causes underlying them.
